abstract_summ: In order to combat the global pandemic of novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), all humans on earth need to make difficult strategic decisions on three very different scales, all fueled by Analytical and Artificial Intelligence-based predictive Models (AAIMs).Abstract We compare the COVID-19 pandemic and 1918-19 influenza pandemic in United Kingdom.Unlike the classic public health and virus propagation models, this new projection model takes government intervention and public response into account to make reliable projections of the outbreak 10 days to 2 weeks in advance.With the worldwide outbreak of COVID-19, an accurate model to predict how the coronavirus pandemic will evolve becomes important and urgent to help policy makers in different countries address the epidemic outbreak and determine policies to control spread more efficiently and effectively.Four months into the ongoing novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, this work provides a simple and direct projection of the outbreak spreading potential and the pandemic cessation dates in China, Iran, the Philippines and Taiwan, using the generalized logistic model (GLM).We found that the on-going COVID-19 wave of infection matched the major wave of the 1918-19 influenza pandemic surprisingly well, both reached similar magnitude (in term of estimated weekly new infections) and spent the same duration above 5 cases per 1000 inhabitants, for the past two months.
title_summ: Doubling time tells how effective Covid-19 prevention worksForecasting COVID-19 pandemic Severity in AsiaA New, Simple Projection Model for COVID-19 PandemicAccelerating the global response against the exponentially growing COVID-19 outbreak through decent data sharingComparing COVID-19 and the 1918–19 influenza pandemics in United KingdomCOVID 19 and Spanish flu pandemics: All it changes, nothing changes.
title_abstract_phrases: In order to combat the global pandemic of novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), all humans on earth need to make difficult strategic decisions on three very different scales, all fueled by Analytical and Artificial Intelligence-based predictive Models (AAIMs).Comparing COVID-19 and the 1918–19 influenza pandemics in United KingdomAbstract We compare the COVID-19 pandemic and 1918-19 influenza pandemic in United Kingdom.Forecasting COVID-19 pandemic Severity in AsiaFour months into the ongoing novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, this work provides a simple and direct projection of the outbreak spreading potential and the pandemic cessation dates in China, Iran, the Philippines and Taiwan, using the generalized logistic model (GLM).A New, Simple Projection Model for COVID-19 PandemicWith the worldwide outbreak of COVID-19, an accurate model to predict how the coronavirus pandemic will evolve becomes important and urgent to help policy makers in different countries address the epidemic outbreak and determine policies to control spread more efficiently and effectively.Accelerating the global response against the exponentially growing COVID-19 outbreak through decent data sharingAbstract COVID-19 is a novel and exponentially-growing disease and consequently the accelerated development of knowledge from good data is possible quickly and globally.We found that the on-going COVID-19 wave of infection matched the major wave of the 1918-19 influenza pandemic surprisingly well, both reached similar magnitude (in term of estimated weekly new infections) and spent the same duration above 5 cases per 1000 inhabitants, for the past two months.
